rsbNotes.title: Ps 37
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 37 An acrostic (Introduction: Characteristics and Themes), and like most acrostics, a wisdom meditation.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 37:13
rsbNotes.text: 37:13 the Lord laughs at the wicked. See Ps. 2:4. Vivid human language describes the folly of rebellion against the Almighty. God is not threatened, nor is His judgment avoided.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 37:15
rsbNotes.text: 37:15 their sword shall enter their own heart. The consequences of sin are frequently the result of its own outworking. See 7:14–16; 34:21; 35:8.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 37:21
rsbNotes.text: 37:21 borrows but does not pay back. The wicked break the eighth commandment, against stealing, by not repaying their debts. The righteous pay their debts and give money generously. Those who give mercifully in God’s cause prosper at last.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 37:24
rsbNotes.text: 37:24 fall. The wise man is not perfect—he may fall in the way. But God guides and protects him even when he sins and encounters obstacles.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 37:25–26
rsbNotes.text: 37:25, 26 Confirming the truth of v. 24, the psalmist draws on the experience of his own long life to assure the upright that God will abandon neither them nor their children. The righteous are known by their deeds of mercy and generosity.
